ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about very foundational practices in Ancient Egyptian and Mesopotamian art.
Comprehensive knowledge of Egyptian and Mesopotamian art, and learning about how to compare them.
I learned so much about the art from two areas I did not know much about!
I learned about the material and cultural history of ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia.

I learned how to look at art critically, and specifically learned more about Mesopotamian and Egyptian art. We also spent time in class comparing art from the two regions, and discussed broader issues affecting art scholarship, including how to display art in museums, repatriation, and forgery.
I leave this course with an understanding of the cultural, geographical, and historical nuances that informed ancient Egyptian and Mesopotamian art.
I learned about symbols and characteristics of Mesopotamian and Egyptian art.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course had little to no structure, and we did not receive any grades.
Very interesting and dynamic, but should be more strict on time---- many activities turned out to be much longer than expected, which disturb the schedule.
I would have loved more sessions where we interacted with the objects themselves!

Strengths: Knowledgable professors, manageable work load

Weaknesses: This course had a lot to offer but at times felt like it was taking on too much. I felt like sometimes we lacked basic historical and cultural understandings of the places we were to talking about to then be able to jump to some of the high level analyses we were being asked to make. I also received no grades or feedback throughout the entire semester which made it difficult to gage where I stood in the class and how I could improve.
This class was great, and I especially enjoyed the field trip to the Met. I would have liked more feedback on my assignments and a more clear assignment schedule throughout the semester.

The course is taught by two amazing, knowledgeable professors who complement each other well. At times, student presentations prevented the seminar from being led as planned which sacrificed course content.
The greatest strength of this course were the instructors who were clearly passionate about the material. I think it could be improved by refining the lessons subjects and improving the structure.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.
Yes! Very interesting and so fun to learn about.
Yes and no. If you really want to learn about these art historical areas and have little to no prior knowledge, an intro course that goes more in depth might be better suited for you.
Yes, I enjoyed this class so much! It inspired me to visit museums and do related readings in my free time.
If you're looking to round out your competencies in ancient art - absolutely!
I would. I came into the course with no knowledge of Egyptian or Mesopotamian art and can now recognize important symbols and works of art from both as well as their similarities.
